Verse two is even simpler than its predecessor and follows the theme of ‘young love’ discovered on the dance-floor. It also begins with another “well, she…” and follows the same rhyme scheme.

These lines are reminiscent of the love-at-first-sight lyrics from May 1967’s “With a Little Help from My Friends.”
[Bridge: Paul McCartney & John Lennon]

Chord Progression:
A (“Well my heart… hand in…”
B A (“Mine,” chord changes underneath the word)

During the word “mine,” even though the chord is going down from a B major to an A major, the melody is going against this, starting at B (root of B major) up to a C# (third in A major), but the A major exists to resolve back to the E major (IV to I) at the beginning of the next verse.
[Verse 1: Paul McCartney, McCartney & John Lennon]

Key: E Major

Chord Progression:
E E A E (“Well she was… what I mean”)
E E B B (“And the way… compare”)
E E A a (“So how could I… another”)
E B E E (“When I saw her standing there”)

The structure of the verse is pretty standard for its era, with the song title being introduced at the end of the verse, and there being no discernible chorus. Instead, the repetition of the title (i.e. the “hook”) is what makes it so memorable, in a similar fashion to Fats Domino’s “Ain’t That a Shame.”

One of the more interesting aspects of the progression for the verse is the utilization of the minor 4th (iv) chord (4th note of scale–in this case an A, which becomes A minor, noted as a lowercase ‘a’).

The Beatles likely picked it up from doo-wop music, and used the technique quite often. The whole structure (melody + progression) also repeats for all remaining verses in the song.

The song was part of The Beatles live routine from its composition (estimated to be at some point between late 1961/early 1962) until 1964, and would be one of Paul’s vessels for his “Little Richard impression”, whose screaming delivery McCartney often imitated.
When I saw her standing there?

After coming up with the original idea, a verse and a rough chorus, McCartney invited Lennon to his childhood home and the pair finished the song together

I wrote it with John in the front parlour of my house in 20 Forthlin Road, Allerton. We sagged off school and wrote it on guitars and a little bit on the piano that I had there.

Mike McCartney’s book, Remember, contains a picture of the pair working on the song, guitars in hand, studying an exercise book of lyrics.
Well, we danced through the night, and we held each other tight

The bassline in this song, played by McCartney as was the standard in all early Beatles records, is a simple blues melody. However, add to this the pure speed at which it is played and the fact that McCartney would simultaneously sing lead vocal and it becomes a rather more challenging piece to play.

McCartney openly admits that he actually stole this bassline almost wholesale from one of his heroes, Chuck Berry’s 1961 single “I’m Talking About You”.

I played exactly the same notes as he did and it fitted our number perfectly. Even now, when I tell people about it, I find few of them believe me.

One, two, three, four!

The Beatles recorded nine takes of this song on Monday, February 11, 1963–and although the first take was considered to be the best, the count-in was spliced into the record by George Martin. He felt it would make an impactful intro to the album.

The cue was actually part of the ninth attempt. When the band was getting frustrated that the record wasn’t quite finished yet, Paul initiated the count-in as a way of pushing everyone to finish the take.

The only overdubs on this song are some handclaps recorded by the band immediately after the nine takes.
And the way she looked was way beyond compare

Paul McCartney explained the songwriting process during the 1995 Anthology series:

We were learning our skill. John would like some of my lines and not others. He liked most of what I did, but there would sometimes be a cringe line, such as, ‘She was just seventeen, she’d never been a beauty queen.’ John thought, ‘Beauty queen? Ugh.’ We were thinking of Butlins so we asked ourselves, what should it be? We came up with, ‘You know what I mean.’ Which was good, because you don’t know what I mean.

The back and forth between Lennon’s harder side and Paul’s softer side can be seen with the line, “the way she looked was way beyond compare”—likely a line Paul wrote that matches up with his “cute” side. The girl in question can’t be compared to anyone else on the dance floor.

She wouldn’t dance with another (Woah)
 When I saw her standing there

The respective vocal styles of Lennon and McCartney are on full display in the hook.

McCartney traditionally wrote vocal lines that contained large, scalar leaps upwards, taking advantage of his impressive vocal register. Here, he follows the E scale up in fairly rudimentary intervals during his line, but then ascends a whole octave for the WHOOH!

John, meanwhile, keeps things far lower on the spectrum. His line delivery is typically cynical and downbeat next to the showman McCartney, and his harmony takes several chromatic steps, staying narrow and turning it into an abrasive counter-melody.
Well, she was just seventeen and you know what I mean

The very first line in The Beatles' discography perfectly captures the Lennon-McCartney songwriting dynamic. McCartney had originally tried the opening line:

Well, she was just seventeen
Never been a beauty queen

After wrangling his head for some time and deciding it just didn’t sound right, he took it to John Lennon. Young Lennon was brash and more inclined to express his rock'n'roll swagger aggressively in his lyrics – this is one of the reasons why Paul became “the cute one” and John was known as “the tough one” during Beatlemania. “Beauty queen” reminded John of Butlins holiday destinations, which made the band cringe – after deliberation, John simply came up with “you know what I mean”, and it stuck:

Which was good, because you don’t know what I mean.
- The Beatles Anthology (p.23)

At a glance, the line implies risqué sexuality, but as McCartney later said in 1968:

People just take our music and a line: we say “She was just seventeen”, and they read everything into that – “she was a seventeen year old nymphomaniac working on the streets of Broadway”, but you know, what we meant is she was just seventeen. It might mean the other as well, I don’t know, you know.
